iati-activity.title: Community Action for Harm Reduction (CAHR) in China, India, Indonesia, Kenya, and Malaysia.
iati-activity.description:
Community Action on Harm Reduction (CAHR) is an ambitious project that aims to expand harm reduction services to more than 180,000 injecting drug users, their partners and children in China, India, Indonesia, Kenya, and Malaysia.
The programmes are being implemented by a consortium of Alliance linking organisations: - Alliance China - International HIV/AIDS Alliance in India - Rumah Cemera, Indonesia - KANCO, Kenya - Malaysian AIDS Council
Their main focus will be on providing HIV and harm reduction services to people who use drugs and their families in the five listed countries. The programme will involve people who use drugs in the design and delivery of services, and is developing advocacy plans to advance the human rights of people who use drugs. There is a strong focus on building the local capacity of community based organisations and sharing knowledge about what works. The project aims to demonstrate in each country how it is possible to reach more people by capitalising on both the infrastructure and the evidence-based approaches of the national AIDS response, in order to scale-up harm reduction programmes quickly.

transaction.description: This is the total value of the contract over the lifetime of the project.

iati-activity.title: Capacity development and advocacy on sexual and reproductive health and rights policies.
iati-activity.description: The objective of this programme is to improve the sexual and reproductive health (SRH) amongst adolescents and young people, especially from the most vulnerable and marginalised groups in India and Bangladesh. The project will increase access to comprehensive SRHR education and services amongst young people, especially from the most vulnerable and marginalised groups in the states of Uttar Pradesh and Manipur (both in India) and the four divisions of Bangladesh.

iati-activity.title: Malawi Bridge Phase II : Promote Normative change and increase preventative behavior in Malawi
iati-activity.description: The overall goal of the BRIDGE II is to promote normative change and increase prevention behaviors among adults in the general population in Malawi. The role of the Alliance is to provide technical support on strengthening referrals and linkages between statutory and non-statutory service providers to increase up-take, follow on and encourage appropriate health seeking behaviours.

iati-activity.title: PROVIC Component 2: Care and support for People Living with HIV/AIDS(PLWHA) and OVC strengthened.
iati-activity.description: Care and support and treatment services for PLWHA and their families are still in their infancy in the DRC. Service availaility and quality vary widelu between different parts of the country. A close focus on families and communities will enable a flexible approach that fosters strong integration of work to strengthen care and support and OVC focused interventions and will be instrumental in creating an effective approacj to mitigating the impacts of HIV and AIDS in these populations.

iati-activity.aidsalliance:donor: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

iati-activity.title: (SUNRISE OVC) Strengthening Local Government Response to Vulnerable Children
iati-activity.description: The SUNRISE-OVC project will support the Uganda Ministry of Gender, Labour and Social Development (MGLSD) to lead and manage the OVC response in close collaboration with local government CBSDs, while, in parallel, appropriate technical resources are channelled to an array of district and community level civil society organizations. The strategy will build on the successful Technical Service Organizations (TSO) model as intermediary organizations that help to rapidly scale up project support across the 80 districts.

transaction.provider-org: United States Agency for International Development (USAID)

iati-activity.title: Youth SRH/HIV Prevention Project: "Together we can grow happy, healthy and safe"
iati-activity.description: The Alliance Zambia Country Office will implement the "Together we will grow up happy, healthy and safe " programme through two community-based partners in Zambia, and in Swaziland. In both countries, integrated services for sexual and reproductive health and HIV are often unavailable in rural areas. Where they do exist, access is often limited by social, logistical and financial barriers. Many young people find it difficult to obtain condoms due to stigmatising attitudes related to sexual activity among young people, especially girls, and the association between condoms and HIV.

transaction.provider-org: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation (SDC)

iati-activity.aidsalliance:donor: Swiss Agency for Development and Co-operation (SDC)

iati-activity.title: Programme Partnership Agreement (PPA) 2011-2014
iati-activity.description:
The International HIV/AIDS Alliance ('the Alliance') focuses on curbing the HIV epidemic in 40 developing countries, making it one of the largest civil society organisations directly contributing to MDG 6. As a global organisation of 36 independent, nationally governed NGOs (called 'Linking Organisations' or LOs) we support thousands of community- based organisations to take effective action to stop the spread of HIV, meet the challenges of AIDS and build healthier communities.
The Alliance uses strategic funding from DFID (and three other strategic donors) to leverage results and help ensure we can document and report at each level of service delivery, to ensure continuity of our LOs and provide greater value for money. We will achieve the following outcomes during the course of this PPA: Outcome 1: Alliance programmes increase access to integrated services to people affected by HIV and AIDS. The Alliance brings HIV prevention, care and support services to some of the poorest and most vulnerable communities around the world. Our geographic priorities are based on need – we work in developing countries where HIV transmission is occurring, and where the groups most affected by HIV are hard to reach or have poor access to services, due to gender inequities, poverty, marginalisation and other structural barriers. Outcome 2: Increased participation by people affected by HIV and AIDS in national and international policy processes. Government services alone will not stop the spread of HIV. These services tend to exclude marginalised groups at highest risk of HIV infection. Curbing the epidemic requires an active, diverse and accountable civil society. Civil society plays an important role in delivering complimentary services, increasing the demand for and access to existing services, and in working at the local level – with households, people and communities – to promote behaviour change and change in social and cultural norms. Outcome 3: More effective community based organisations deliver quality HIV programmes and hold governments to account.We build the human and financial capacity required to carry out community-led and community-based interventions. Our model of working through national, independent intermediary organisations to build the capacity of community- based organisations has proved an effective mechanism for bringing programmes to scale while at the same time holding governments to account. This model has been externally evaluated. "The Alliance stands out from other more internationally-driven and managed approaches, with its emphasis on building linked but independent national intermediaries and implementing partners and on supporting the mobilisation of direct funding to national partners to reduce financial dependency" The model has stood the test of 17 years.

transaction.description: This is the total value of the contract over the lifetime of the project.
